Simply not as satisfying as the original.
An immensely skillful sci-fi adventure.
Reloaded seems less tired than X2.
Smart, sexy, and action-rammed.
Buckle up and enjoy the ride.
A kinetic, digital feat.
A worthy sequel.

actors: Clint Eastwood, Tommy Lee Jones, Donald Sutherland, James Garner, James Cromwell, Marcia Gay Harden, William Devane, Loren Dean, Courtney B. Vance, Barbara Babcock, Rade Serbedzija, Blair Brown, Jay Leno, Nils Allen Stewart, Deborah Jolly
genres: Action & Adventure, Comedy, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: Clint Eastwood, Tommy Lee Jones, Donald Sutherland and James Garner star as a group of pilots whose time has come to serve their country and fulfill their dream of going to space. In 1958, the members of Team Daedalus, a group of top Air Force test pilots, were ready to serve their country as the first Americans in space. When NASA replaced the Air Force for outer atmospheric testing, they were pushed aside for a chimpanzee. The team retired, but the dream of going into space never died.
review_content: ...an equivocal movie that can't seem to decide whether to play its ridiculous premise straight.
The talent of the four stars makes up for anything that's less than envelope-pushing waggery.
The ingratiating cast pulls off their mission with the ease of the old pros that they are.
It's light-years away from being an Eastwood classic, but it passes a likable two hours.
Where Armageddon merely strutted, Cowboys swaggers. What's the difference? Style.
Our parents will love it. We're gonna get tired of it really quickly.
... far-fetched and preposterous, but too much fun to worry about it.
Overall, the movie is good enough to warrant a looksie.
This movie delivers the goods and gets out of the way.
Armageddon for people who hated Armageddon.
There is much potential with the cast.
A kiddie movie for adults.
There's plenty to enjoy, particularly the performances, which feature enviable natural chemistry between the leads and a movie-stealing turn by Sutherland as the libidinous O'Neill.
Without succumbing to bitterness or nostalgia or overstating the case for one generation's virtues, [Eastwood] and his cohorts mount a vigorous and funny defense of maturity.
It's a rare pleasure to watch four terrific actors having the time of their lives.
There's an abundance of charm and screen presence from the four veteran actors.
Space Cowboys is a blast for those who don't mind geriatric heroes.
A comic masterpiece of full rear male nudity.
Space Cowboys is the summer's best movie.
Even star power can get lost in space.

actors: Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Rip Torn, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, Patrick Warburton, Jack Kehler, David Cross, Colombe Jacobsen-Derstine, Peter Spellos, Michael Rivkin, Michael Bailey Smith, Lenny Venito
movie_info: Kay (Tommy Lee Jones) and Jay (Will Smith) reunite to provide our best line of defense against a seductress who levels the toughest challenge yet to the MIBs mission statement: protecting the earth from the scum of the universe. While investigating a routine crime, Jay uncovers a plot masterminded by Serleena (Boyle), a Kylothian monster who disguises herself as a lingerie model. When Serleena takes the MIB building hostage, there is only one person Jay can turn to -- his former MIB partner.
review_content: Although the sequel has all the outward elements of the original, the first film's lovely flakiness is gone, replaced by the forced funniness found in the dullest kiddie flicks.
MIB II is faithful to its source film, which in turn sprang from a comic book. But this feels more like submission to formula than devotion to inspiration.
It's fun while you're watching it, but you may well feel as if Smith obliterated your memories of the flick five minutes later with his neutralizer.
Returning director Barry Sonnenfeld and stars Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones try to give us more of the same. But staleness has replaced hipness.
Men in Black II, with its agreeably slipshod feel, is even slighter than the 1997 original, but as summer blockbusters go, it's shameless fun.
It's not nearly as fresh or enjoyable as its predecessor, but there are enough high points to keep this from being a complete waste of time.
A good-faith attempt has been made to duplicate the original elements, but the mix is wrong, bearings have been lost, the balance is off.
Even with its brief running time of 82 minutes, much of the extravagant but lightweight Men in Black II seems labored.
If you're looking for a movie as good as the first, you'd better rent 1997's MIB at the local video store.
This is effective button-pushing sci-fi entertainment, but you won't need to be neurolized to forget it.
'Men in Black II creates a new threat for the MIB, but recycles the same premise.
The picture's definitely entertaining, in fits and starts. It's also joyless.
A mixed bag of a comedy that can't really be described as out of this world.
No more than a soulless exercise in repetitive summer blockbusting.
In every way an improvement over the original Men in Black.
Runs a quick 80 minutes and yet it still feels padded.
As summer escapism goes, you could do worse.
After five years, the chemistry has curdled.
MIB II hits its marks reliably enough.
A lot of setup for too little payoff.

actors: Grant Cramer, Suzanne Snyder, John Allen Nelson, John Vernon, Michael S. Siegel, Peter Licassi, Royal Dano, Christopher Titus, Irene Michaels, Karla Sue Krull, Aeron Macintyre, Danny Kovacs, Adele Proom, Howard Malpas, Karen Raff
movie_info: When teenagers Mike (Grant Cramer) and Debbie (Suzanne Snyder) see a comet crash outside their sleepy small town, they investigate and discover a pack of murderous aliens who look very much like circus clowns. They try to warn the local authorities, but everyone assumes their story is a prank. Meanwhile, the clowns set about harvesting and eating as many people as they can. It's not until they kidnap Debbie that Mike decides it's up to him to stop the clowns' bloody rampage.
review_content: The title alone encourages immediate dismissal, but for those on the hunt for something miles away from the norm that showcases truly inspired moviemaking minds, Killer Klowns from Outer Space is a superb cult distraction.
Truly something special for genre fans or for those with a love of fun, imaginative films with a ridiculous premise, classic soundtrack, and a blackly humorous edge
The imagination that went into the visual effects, the set design, and the alien gadgetry makes it easy to overlook any minor deficiencies in other departments.
A few more eerie moments could have offset the hokiness; the body count is high, but the gore is too limited.
Boy, you know, I really like the Chiodo Brothers' Killer Klowns from Outer Space. I can't help it.
'Can't Sleep, Clowns Will Eat Me.' Not just pretty words, thanks to the Chiodo brothers.
IT'S GOT CLOWNS! FROM OUTER SPACE! AND THEY'RE KILLING PEOPLE! What's not to like?
The title says it all...and is the only reason to see this misfire.
Warped fun with memorably weird ideas, effects and costumes
Yes, it's goofy but the klowns really are killer.
The name says it all, and the movie delivers.
As if clowns weren't already scary enough

actors: Chris Pine, Zachary Quinto, Leonard Nimoy, Eric Bana, Bruce Greenwood, Karl Urban, Zoe Saldana, Simon Pegg, John Cho, Anton Yelchin, Ben Cross, Winona Ryder, Chris Hemsworth, Jennifer Morrison, Rachel Nichols
genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: Aboard the USS Enterprise, the most-sophisticated starship ever built, a novice crew embarks on its maiden voyage. Their path takes them on a collision course with Nero (Eric Bana), a Romulan commander whose mission of vengeance threatens all mankind. If humanity would survive, a rebellious young officer named James T. Kirk (Chris Pine) and a coolly logical Vulcan named Spock (Zachary Quinto) must move beyond their rivalry and find a way to defeat Nero before it is too late.
review_content: The aim here is to court a new generation of fans without alienating the true believers speaking Klingon in the box-office lines.
The summer movie season has barely begun, but already one thing is certain: It will have at least one indisputably great movie.
A film that should appeal to longtime Trekkies, sci-fi neophytes and pretty much anybody who likes a good action flick.
It boldly goes somewhere different and makes it hard to leave the film not hoping for a return voyage soon.
J. J. Abrams's thriller Star Trek is the first tent-pole film that has made me sob with pure pleasure.
It's an exciting, stellar-yet-earthy blast that successfully blends the hip and the classic.
That jolt of energy may resuscitate the franchise; its breathing, however, feels shallow.
hen it comes to sheer spectacle, Star Trek, as re-imagined by J.J. Abrams, delivers.
The happy result is action-friendly, nerd-friendly, and fundamentally optimistic.
Star Trek used to be smarter. But it was never this fast, fresh and exciting.
One of the most accessible and entertaining films of the year.
You couldn't ask for a less ponderous, more rollicking time.
Abrams' redo isn't just a blast from the past. It's a blast.
With a crew like this, you can welcome the future.
Take note, George Lucas: This is how it's done.
Highly illogical but entertaining as hell.
Well, at least they got it half right.
Summer officially hits warp speed.
Smart, epic and eye-popping.
Phasers set on "stunning."

actors: Thure Lindhardt, Vanessa Kirby, David Ajala, Mike Noble, Bentley Kalu, Tom McKay, Kelly Gough, Osi Okerafor, Damian Kell, Tim Ahern, Sam Huntington
genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: In the near future, a training exercise leads to a fight for survival when Marines encounter advanced military robots on a remote island.
review_content: The plot is basically that of Walter Hill's Southern Comfort, but with robots instead of rednecks (something I never knew I wanted until I saw Kill Command) and a healthy dash of the Alien franchise thrown in for good measure.

Kill Command punches above its low-budget weight thanks to its smart visuals and intriguing plot, even if it does owe a significant debt in style and storytelling to the likes of RoboCop and Terminator.
You won't give a mechanical monkey's uncle what happens to any of the generic grunts... but there's still some fun to be had in the well-executed action sequences and superbly-realised killer robots.
Steven Gomez's sci-fi thriller comes on like the ultimate James Cameron homage and fortunately, the retro vibe extends to the storytelling, which is a brisk and well-judged balance.
This science-fiction film takes a horror film premise - a small group of people are picked off one by one by a ruthless foe - and manages to strip it almost completely of scares.
As robo thrillers go, this has its moments, but the mechanical script could have used a little more in the way of human warmth.
This low-budget robot war has a lot more going for it than many bloated Hollywood studio equivalents.
A film that defies the somewhat limited budget provided.
Kill Command mostly sucks. Mostly.
Gamers will have a bit of deja vu watching this, but it is a well managed movie with some cool, controlled performances among the detonations.

actors: Nicolas Cage, Julianne Moore, Jessica Biel, Thomas Kretschmann, Tory Kittles, José Zúñiga, Jim Beaver, Jason Butler Harner, Michael Trucco, Enzo Cilenti, Laetitia Danielle, Nicolas Pajon, Sergej Trifunovic, Charles Rahi Chun, Patricia Prata
movie_info: Blessed, or cursed, with the ability to see events minutes before they occur, Cris Johnson (Nicolas Cage) earns a living as a magician in Las Vegas and keeps a low profile under an alias. When terrorists threaten to detonate a nuclear weapon in Los Angeles, government agent Callie Ferris (Julianne Moore) goes on the hunt for Cris and hopes to convince him to help her stop the coming apocalypse.
review_content: The film fails to play by a consistent set of rules and, while it's possible to justify that endgame twist, that doesn't mean it's a good idea. Some viewers will feel cheated by what Next does, and it's hard to blame them.
Late in the movie, Cris shouts at a bad guy, 'I've seen every possible ending here. None of them are good for you.' It's as if he's talking to the audience, and alas, he's right.
Cage is cool, quiet and a touch melancholy as Johnson -- carrying the burden of his gift with a brooding brow and a ready punch line.
Time is of the essence in the new sci-fi thriller Next, and all the major players wear expensive watches to prove it.
It is so preposterous it could almost be the spoof "bad action movie" they'd keep flashing to in a Hollywood satire.
It [explores] different facets of its premise and transforms itself into a fairly competent suspense thriller.
This one experiments with the putatively brain-frying idea of a man who can see two minutes into the future.
It's too bad that Mr. Cage couldn't tap into those powers to save himself from another bad choice in roles.
Once you know the rules, it's hardly worth playing. Especially when you find out you've been tricked.
Next, which makes National Treasure look like a model of narrative logic, is almost beyond criticism.
Next begins to seriously embarrass itself and its stars once it rolls to its climax.
Next comes across like a standard clock-puncher for almost everyone involved.
A routine action film with strange bits of surreal time-flopping mixed in.
A schlocky mix of bad special effects and worse Cage hairdos.
It's just a shame that none of the laughs are intentional.
If this all sounds like tripe, that's because it is.
Good summer fun that's both brain and eye candy.
Who says preposterous junk can't be fun?
Watchably absurd popcorn flick.
Colossal waste of time.

actors: Clive Owen, Afiya Bennett, Morgan Allen, Jeffrey Men, James Tam, Amanda Seyfried, Jonathan Potts, Rachel Roberts, Toyin Ishola, Sebastian Pigott, David Storch, Billy Parrott, Amadou Kebe, Stephanie Christian, Natalie Chaves
movie_info: In the near future, private memories are recorded and crime has almost ceased to exist. But in trying to solve a series of murders, troubled detective Sal Frieland stumbles upon a young woman known only as "The Girl." She has no identity, no history and is invisible to the cops. Sal realizes this may not be the end of crime, and it could be the beginning of it.
review_content: The big aesthetic misstep is the film's claustrophobic, suffocating reliance on a greyed-out color palette.
Not the Andrew Niccol "comeback" one might have hoped for. Stylish, striking but empty.
There's enough bandwidth in the compelling, stylishly visualised concept to sustain it.
An intriguing watch, even if the too clever by half story runs out of puff early on.
An undeniably stylish-looking film noir but is hampered by an overworked screenplay.
A tepid crime movie that uses technology and graphics merely to add a bit of zest.
It is cold, detached and one note - a note so subdued it becomes soporific.
Owen doesn't so much chew the scenery as have a staring match with it.
Anon ends up feeling like a cheerless retread of Minority Report.
All we're missing is a story worth caring about.
The ideas are interesting; the execution isn't.
Packed with fascinating touches.

In its weaker moments, Anon feels less like a traditional detective story than an exercise in computer search engine sleuthing. Too many digital bells and whistles get in the way of an otherwise conventional detective story.
The script's heady intent proves to be exhausting, reducing a third act twist to a shoulder shrug, and a seemingly profound final line about life off the grid into a blank expression.
Now we can add Seyfried's confident and subtle work as a character known only as the Girl in "Anon," a slick and satisfying mind-trip of a sci-fi murder mystery.
The story works well enough in its own moodily familiar way, but it's not only the movie's palette that's stylishly leached of color...
Andrew Niccol brings another of his Philip K Dick-style futurist high concepts to the movie screen, and it doesn't entirely come off.
Anon's storyline is forgettable and the movie ends with an unsatisfying mixture of confusion and predictability.
Ends up like an episode of Black Mirror without the jokes. Or much of the drama.
Entertaining and intriguing - even if it provokes privacy concerns.

actors: Lou Taylor Pucci, Chris Pine, Piper Perabo, Emily VanCamp, Christopher Meloni, Kiernan Shipka, Ron McClary, Mark Moses, Josh Berry, Tim D. Janis, Dale Malley, Dylan Kenin, LeAnne Lynch, Jan Cunningham, Mary Peterson
genres: Drama, Horror, Mystery & Suspense, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: When a virus threatens to wipe out humanity, Danny (Lou Taylor Pucci), his brother Brian (Chris Pine), and their friends Bobby (Piper Perabo) and Kate (Emily VanCamp) set out across the desert in the Southwest, trying to elude the pandemic. Over the course of several days, the four friends learn that the darkness within themselves may prove deadlier than any microbe.
review_content: "Humorless B-film on a post-apocalyptic global air-borne viral pandemic that is wiping out the earth's population.
It's no candidate for greatness, but it deserves to find an audience among connoisseurs of doomsday cinema.
A thoughtful effort, a meditative treatise on the ethics of survival in a land where all hope is lost.
A solid drama about pettiness, individualism and foolishness. [full review in Spanish]
Diverting and well made with solid performances, but Carriers adds nothing new.
A moody, engaging end-of-the-world horror-drama, if a bit too apocalypse-lite.
Never less than engrossing, this is one trip you won't want to make.
engaging despite its downbeat message and lack of zombie action.
The anti-Zombieland - a darker, more intense look at humanity.
Gloom, not thrills, in sci-fi drama of worldwide plague.
An enjoyably dark, emotionally gripping thriller.
Brings absolutely nothing new to the table.
Carriers is grimmer than necessary.
click to read the full review
This thoughtful, low-key exploration of our darker survival instincts is too conventional and unfocused to fully engage our emotions.
Sadly it loses track of its own best ideas, pledging itself to a dreary set of surviving characters whose choices carry no charge.
Plays like Zombieland's humourless twin: with none of the gags and, unfortunately, not many of its genuine moments of tension.
In lacking both subtley and specatcle... Carriers timidly takes its place in the realms of forgettable science-fiction fodder.
The movie has as much depth as the single piece of paper on which the script was obviously written.
A queasy mixture of survivalist machismo and mawkish piety.

actors: Alison Brie, Molly Shannon, Goldenite, Stella Chestnut, John Ortiz, Lauren Weedman, Hazel Armenante, Robin Tunney, Matthew Gray Gubler, Debby Ryan, Jake Picking, Mary Apick, Toby Huss, Angela Trimbur, Aaron Stanford
movie_info: A woman's surreal dreams affect her perception of reality.
review_content: Horse Girl features a superb performance from writer-star Alison Brie while the film also has something to say about mental illness.
By the end, viewers have whiplash and a distinct sensation that the script needed several more drafts, but they aren't bored.
A dark movie that gets weird for no good reason, a victim of writers who can't figure out the ending to their story.
I am certain of two things: this is one doozy of a watch and Alison Brie is at the height of her performing powers.
What starts off seeming like a quirky rom-com quickly morphs into something far more disturbing, and strange.
A luminous and colorful indie with surprising amounts of realism. [Full Review in Spanish]
There is a lot going on in Horse Girl (2020), and it very nearly manages to pull it off.
...the movie as a whole is such a compelling dive down the rabbit hole.
HORSE GIRL is a flick that bites off more than it can chew.
Young woman battles mental illness; sex/nudity, language.
Enter Horse Girl with an open mind and enjoy the ride.
The ambition of Horse Girl ultimately gets the better of it, turning what could be a dark but insightful depiction on signs missed in a mental health crisis into an agreement on one's madness
The way Brie shows you Sarah slowly slipping out of reality-then steeply sliding further down a snake pit of instability-gives you the sense that she's flexing a new set of muscles.
There are indications that "Horse Girl" and its creators have something to say about the sorry state of mental health care in this country... but it's never explored beyond basics.
Brie is rawly convincing as a troubled woman for whom the sides of reality have become too slippery, transformed into the heroine of a private sci-fi melodrama.
Horse Girl's big weakness is that it can't decide how much ambiguity to provide its central character, or how seriously it wants to present Sarah's breakdown.
The sincerity that Brie brings to her full-fledged embodiment of mental illness is major, and in turn helps Horse Girl overcome its tricky storytelling.
An empathetic depiction of mental illness, but the film fails to clear the hurdle it sets itself.
Brie's performance is open and honest and disturbing and funny and lovely and resonant.
I found the experience of watching Horse Girl to be more of a chore than a pleasure.

actors: Warren Christie, Lloyd Owen, Ryan Robbins, Michael Kopsa, Andrew Airlie, Kurt Max Runte, Jan Bos, Kim Wylie, Noah Wylie, Ali Liebert, Erica Carroll
movie_info: Apollo 17 was the last U.S.-sponsored lunar voyage -- or was it? Hours of found footage, classified for decades, point to a subsequent moon mission -- Apollo 18 -- that ended very badly. Astronauts John Grey (Ryan Robbins), Nathan Walker (Lloyd Owen) and Benjamin Anderson (Warren Christie), on a mission to install radar scanners, discover a Soviet space capsule nearby. The men also discover a dead cosmonaut, and unfortunately for them, learn how he died.
review_content: An astonishingly incompetent and interminable piece of work...
Dull, but diverting if you focus on the images' eerie beauty.
In other words, this found footage should've stayed hidden.
The only thing worse than an inept filmmaker is a lazy one.
An intriguing premise that never quite reaches liftoff.
The basics are there; it just can't run with them.
More than just a lunar 'Paranormal Activity.'
[It] really delivers a fun, tense experience.
A drab and shoddy experimental film.
[A] zero-intensity space bore.
nauseatingly bad
The film takes a startlingly long time to rev up, and even at less than 90 minutes feels thin and at moments like it is playing for time.
Has no thrills, no chills, no scares and contains a villain, or several of them, actually, that will turn you to stone -- from boredom.
The source of the creepy events, when it's finally revealed, is profoundly dull, like a forgettable episode of The X-Files or Fringe.
Accomplishes something the world wasn't really crying out for: it recreates the tedium of watching the later Apollo missions.
Boredom sets in long before the last muted shriek. And who cares about the astros? We never get to know them anyway.
Apollo 18 fails to stay with you because, like the cratered satellite on which it's set, it has no atmosphere.
It's not awful - you just wish they'd made a proper movie out of it.
Make no mistake, Apollo 18 is a *terrible* movie.
For most horror fans it will be kind of a snooze.

actors: Dwayne Johnson, Jessica Biel, Justin Long, Gary Oldman, Seann William Scott, John Cleese, Freddie Benedict, Alan Marriott, Mathew Horne, James Corden, Lewis Macleod, Emma Tate, Rupert Degas, Pete Atkin, Rebecca Front
genres: Action & Adventure, Animation, Comedy, Kids & Family
movie_info: When astronaut Capt. Charles "Chuck" Baker lands on Planet 51, he thinks he is the first life form to set foot there. He gets the surprise of his life when he learns that it is inhabited by little green people who live in an idyllic version of 1950s America -- complete with a universal fear of alien invasion.
review_content: Just how much of this will be appreciated by children is questionable, but the film is clearly intended to keep them happy with lashings of colour, movement and cheesy jokes while older, diehard geeks can enjoy all the reference spotting.

It's frenetic and knowing in the modern manner, though, a couple of good gags apart, not very funny. Its patchiness merely demonstrates the gap between Pixar and the rest of the field - which is the distance between genius and talent.

The movie as a whole isn't exactly ground-breaking, and some of the humor tanks. But it has enough action, laughs and candy-hued visuals to satisfy the target audience without plunging grown-ups into despair.
Delivers a few pleasant surprises, including a smart story -- a reverse-E.T. riff that plops an American astronaut down in a world of just-like-us-only-green creatures -- and clever characters...
With nowhere to go except toward that incongruous moral, the story is getting thin on the ground, obliging director Jorge Blanco to pad with the usual +h stuffing -- bland action and busy edits.
It could have added up to something. Alas, any excitement is submerged by the relentless barrage of trite sci-fi allusions and nudge-nudge gags aimed solely at adults.
Rest assured that nothing of significance will disturb said infant, neither feelings nor images nor ideas. No danger here; just a faint, faraway tickle of boredom.
Instead of spinning its spoof of 1950s sci-fi paranoia in new directions, the movie trades in potty humor and tired sendups of The Terminator and Star Wars.
Good fun if you can put up with the pastel colours and plasticky textures, which show that in modern fantasy animation all that pixellates isn't Pixar.
Well and truly aimed at kids, Planet 51 is a film they will thoroughly enjoy yet which any accompanying adult will have lots of laughs in too.
Young children and adults with high pain thresholds will enjoy the movie during its brief pause on the way to your On Demand menu.
The agreeable but flagrantly unoriginal Planet 51 belongs to the mix-and-match school of animated moviemaking.
Although not bowling me over, Planet 51 is a jolly and good-looking animated feature in glorious 2-D.
Largely, it's a jellybean of a movie: bright, colorful, sugary, and with no real content.
This sharp-looking but unimaginative adventure hasn't the wit of similar kiddie flicks.
There's enough of a storyline here to keep younger space cadets moderately settled.
A hideously annoying and emotionally blank tale.
Mediocre, clunky and just so not special.
Planet 51 is cute, but it's no Shrek.
Definitely a planet worth a visit.

actors: Arnold Schwarzenegger, Rachel Ticotin, Sharon Stone, Ronny Cox, Michael Ironside, Marshall Bell, Mel Johnson Jr., Michael Champion, Roy Brocksmith, Ray Baker, Rosemary Dunsmore, David Knell, Alexia Robinson, Dean Norris, Mark Carlton
genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Mystery & Suspense, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: Douglas Quaid (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is a bored construction worker in the year 2084 who dreams of visiting the colonized Mars. He visits "Rekall," a company that plants false memories into people's brains, in order to experience the thrill of Mars without having to travel there. But something goes wrong during the procedure; Quaid discovers that his entire life is actually a false memory and that the people who implanted it in his head now want him dead.
review_content: Mediocre sci-fi. Gained a cult following, for some unknown reason.
Worryingly satisfying in a purely gruesome, beat-em-up kinda way.
Overall, the movie's imaginative effects and ideas win the day.
Mindless, harmless popcorn flick. Emphasis on the mindless.
Oh for the days when Verhoeven was still in Holland.
Thought-provoking, flashy, and FULL of action!
...people are allowed to change their minds
Ridiculous, but also plenty of fun
Mind-bending psychodrama.
There may be people who overlook the Arnold Schwarzenegger performance in Total Recall who think he isn't really acting. But the performance is one of the reasons the movie works so well.
Schwarzenegger is never going to make the De Niros and Hoffmans of this world lose a night's sleep, but he has acquired a new confidence as an actor under Verhoeven's guidance.
It's still a guilty pleasure - though the guilt quotient is a bit higher - and that's down to the still-extraordinary presence of the massively gym-built Arnold...
Total Recall begins to self-destruct not long after Schwarzenegger arrives on Mars, and the story degenerates into a violent, stunningly foul-mouthed enterprise.
If Total Recall isn't as much fun as I'd hoped, it's not as dreary as I'd feared. I wouldn't call it totally awesome, but it's far from being a total loss.
As Quaid, Schwarzenegger continues to stretch beyond his reach as an actor, relying on physical prowess to keep him in character.
Total Recall is slick, sly and subversive, and if some of the special effects have aged somewhat, that only adds to the charm.
It's not a masterpiece, but it is a fast-moving thriller, one worth revisiting (and, evidently, remaking).
Neither Arnold Schwarzenegger nor Paul Verhoeven have stretched their talents here.
Still a ripsnorting yarn with lashings of sex and violence that hasn't aged a day.
Total Recall is too much -- but it's too much of a good thing.

actors: Lizzy Caplan, Jessica Lucas, T.J. Miller, Michael Stahl-David, Mike Vogel, Odette Annable, Anjul Nigam, Margot Farley, Theo Rossi, Brian Klugman, Kelvin Yu, Liza Lapira, Lili Mirojnick, Ben Feldman, Elena Nikitina Bick
genres: Action & Adventure, Mystery & Suspense, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: As a group of New Yorkers (Michael Stahl-David, Mike Vogel, Odette Yustman) enjoy a going-away party, little do they know that they will soon face the most terrifying night of their lives. A creature the size of a skyscraper descends upon the city, leaving death and destruction in its wake. Using a handheld video camera, the friends record their struggle to survive as New York crumbles around them.
review_content: It puts human faces on the victims of mass destruction, faces that might easily have been yours or mine, staring down the maw of something we don't understand.
The shaky video camera perspective is alternately involving and irritating, but director Matt Reeves keeps the carnival of wreckage spinning at a brisk clip.
There's nothing to Cloverfield, really, but stripped-down chaos shot in a faux-verite Blair Witch Project fashion...But I have to say, I was with it.
It's a giant-monster movie from the point of view of some of those little people running and shrieking in the street -- and it works incredibly well.
While it [the "camcorder ploy"] injects the film with a run-and-gun urgency, the device grows tiresome and ultimately leaves the film shortchanged.
A jolt to the genre. The camera tumbles, the smoke billows, gigantic footsteps thunk, women shriek and the car alarms blare. And we are there.
Cloverfield is visceral attack that it leaves the viewer reeling for details that flew by like so many bricks raining off broken buildings.
A surprisingly gripping thriller. Employing a pseudo-documentary handheld camera style, it offers a fresh spin on the monster movie genre.
A remarkably economical, street-level view of widespread panic caused by an abomination that gets, and ultimately needs, no explanation.
It's like Abrams and crew have looked into the void and thought: the only thing worse than Armageddon is if no one witnessing it is hot.
A terrific movie, filled with spectacle and a surprising amount of humor, which makes up for its lack of terror or emotional impact.
An effective film, deploying its special effects well and never breaking the illusion that it is all happening as we see it.
The running and climbing, the tidal waves of debris rushing down the avenues, the screams and carnage grow tiresome.
A twitchy thrill ride that's relentless in its escalation of tension, merciless in its intensity.
A surreptitiously subversive, stylistically clever little gem of an entertainment.
This film takes you into the heart of the maelstrom and leaves you there.
Smartly reconjures the 1950s monster movie for the digital age.
An efficiently gripping sci-fi/horror romp.
Fully visceral, visually impressive.
It's fun in its morbidly campy way.

country: Germany, France, Canada, UK, China, USA
actors: Milla Jovovich, Ali Larter, Kim Coates, Shawn Roberts, Sergio Peris-Mencheta, Spencer Locke, Boris Kodjoe, Wentworth Miller, Sienna Guillory, Kacey Clarke, Norman Yeung, Fulvio Cecere, Raymond Olubawale, Christopher Kano, Tatsuya Goke
genres: Action & Adventure, Horror, Mystery & Suspense, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: In a world overrun with the walking dead, Alice (Milla Jovovich) continues her battle against Umbrella Corp., rounding up survivors along the way. Joined by an old friend, Alice and her group set out for a rumored safe haven in Los Angeles. Instead of sanctuary, they find the city overrun with zombies, and a trap about to spring.
review_content: The very definition of 'switch your brain off' entertainment.
An adaptation which will soon feel decades behind its time.
Been there, done that, pass the console.
... 3-D, where bad sequels go to die ...
full review at Movies for the Masses
The plot? Does it matter?
Actually shot in 3-D.
Dead on arrival.

This witless installment features the usual ultra-slow-motion mayhem and helpful freeze-frames to allow us to admire the extra dimension. Fans will not be happy, however, to learn that Ms. Jovovich is more decently clothed this time around.

The films always look good and have well-staged action, but they don't have one iota of originality or imagination -- to the extent of virtually recreating key scenes from The Matrix, Die Hard and The Descent.
The action is easier to read than in most films of the genre, and therefore more enjoyable. Anderson makes particular use of sets and locations to wring out more bang for the stereoscopic buck.
Resident Evil's appeal as a series is almost exclusively rooted in Jovovich's charisma. She combines the enigmatic magnetism of a silent-movie siren with the bravado of an action hero.
Bound to please the legions of Milla fans who have doubtless poured over the extras-rich DVDs of the first three Resident Evils, as well as her please-sequel-this gem Ultra Violet.
Afterlife is slow-moving but relentless, and judging from a post-credits teaser that promises at yet another sequel, it has an unquenchable appetite for your brain cells.
Whether or not you are a series regular, you are unlikely to encounter anything here that you haven't met before in the sci-fi/horror movie universe.
Resident Evil: Afterlife lacks the humanity -- interesting characters, funny one-liners -- that made its predecessors enjoyable B-movies.
Anderson makes often-inspiring use of the 3-D effects, though he never quite tops the opening Shibuya Crossing bloodbath.
It's a humorless movie of morphing zombies (they take on beastly attributes), phoned-in performances and trite dialogue.
Like pretty much all of Anderson's films, this one is half-baked. The half that's baked isn't too bad, though.
Milla Jovovich sashays through the ludicrous mayhem once more, this time in 3D.

actors: Jim Parsons, Rihanna, Steve Martin, Jennifer Lopez, Matt Jones, Brian Stepanek, April Lawrence, Stephen Kearin, Lisa Stewart, April Winchell
genres: Action & Adventure, Animation, Comedy, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: After a hive-minded alien race called the Boov conquer the Earth, they relocate the planet's human population -- all except for a little girl named Tip (Rihanna), who's managed to hide from the aliens. When Tip meets a fugitive Boov called Oh (Jim Parsons), there's mutual distrust. However, Oh is not like his comrades; he craves friendship and fun. As their distrust fades, the pair set out together to find Tip's mother, but, unbeknown to them, the Gorg -- enemies of the Boov -- are en route.
review_content: It works moderately well thanks largely to the voice talents of Jim Parsons and, to a lesser extent, Steve Martin. Two droll dudes who put a fair share of funny into this animated picture.
While watching "Home," a comical animated spin on alien-attack thrillers with the usual tacked-on touchy-feely messages, I began to get bored as did the families seated around me.
The film moves quickly and keeps the jokes coming, which only means that "Home" would rather keep young viewers occupied than give them something to think about.
Aside from Parsons' initially amusingly mangled Yoda-like English, which gets a tad repetitive, Home doesn't stand out as fresh or particularly funny.
DreamWorks movies are often about outsiders learning that they don't have to fit in, a lesson the filmmakers may not have absorbed themselves.
Inoffensive but flavourless, and crammed with familiar elements from better movies like  Lilo and Stitch ,  Toy Story  and  Despicable Me .
Frenetic direction and supercharged cuteness pitch in to aid in the distraction, and it's almost enough to produce a kind of numbness.
The combination of Home's layered message, fun score, and clever comedy make it a colorful choice for moviegoers of any age.
The film combines wit with mind-boggling inanity but is so brash and good-natured that it is very hard to dislike.
The film takes the lazy route of cannibalising pop cultural references rather than coming up with decent jokes.
The Gummi-colored animation is imaginative, but director Tim Johnson's ho-hum 3D cartoon remains strictly 1D.
Heartwarming and harmless? Sure, why not. But it's also numbing in its simplicity and often rather annoying.
I brought a couple of my kids, who liked it fine and found the friendship at the center rather affecting.
When we scratch beneath the sugary surface, there's something tart inside that's difficult to digest.
Key characters are admirably diverse, but the fast-paced tale is thoroughly predictable.
This kiddie sci-fi adaptation doesn't quite live up to its evocative title.
An earnest exercise that falls flat, despite the best of intentions.
Like the timorous Boov, "Home" has little interest in risk-taking.
An entertaining odd-couple comedy on very traditional lines ...
Lazy gags, and it's been done better elsewhere.

actors: Ian McKellen, Bimbo Hart, Alastair MacIntosh, David Kelly, Ben Barnes, Kate Magowan, Melanie Hill, Charlie Cox, Sienna Miller, Henry Cavill, Nathaniel Parker, Darby Hawker, Frank Ellis, Peter O'Toole, Mark Strong
genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: To win the heart of his beloved (Sienna Miller), a young man named Tristan (Charlie Cox) ventures into the realm of fairies to retrieve a fallen star. What Tristan finds, however, is not a chunk of space rock, but a woman (Claire Danes) named Yvaine. Yvaine is in great danger, for the king's sons need her powers to secure the throne, and an evil witch (Michelle Pfeiffer) wants to use her to achieve eternal youth and beauty.
review_content: Though the special effects are at times a little more elaborate than necessary, they don't overwhelm the story's human scale.
No, Stardust isn't a children's movie. It's a movie for anyone, of any age, who believes in magic -- or wishes they did.
Stardust comes as close as any newfangled fairy tale in recent years to sating the appetite of dream-hungry moviegoers.
Stardust suffers from uneven pacing and some cheesy-looking special effects. But the fine cast keeps things watchable.
For audiences tired of summer sequels that grind through the familiar motions, Stardust provides a dizzying antidote.
It's the closest the movies have come in a while to the nudgy, knowing fairy-tale enchantment of The Princess Bride.
The movie assumes that its churning energy, lightened with whimsy, will carry the day. And, to an extent, it does.
Despite its faults, Stardust should at least be accounted a partial success - and certainly more than a failure.
It brings too much of everything to the table: It's the cinema equivalent of a long, winding, run-on sentence.
Vaughn pays scant attention to the niceties of a well-told story and buries his shekels in a sparkling cast.
Massively pretty to look at, Stardust bursts with (original novel) author Gaiman's trademark invention.
Unfortunately, putting witches in a script does not guarantee magic. Stardust simply has no sparkle.
It feels a bit tired, a bit formulaic, a bit like too much studio input and script doctoring.
A wackily surreal, primary-coloured fairytale from a graphic novel by Neil Gaiman.
The movie isn't remotely as sardonic or irreverent as it so clearly wants to be.
We can tell you this: Your own pure escapism is assured.
Stardust piles on the conflict and the bombast.
The stuff dreams are made of.
Stardust has a welcome heft.
Brutally disappointing.

actors: Guy Pearce, Maggie Grace, Vincent Regan, Joseph Gilgun, Lennie James, Peter Stormare, Jacky Ido, Tim Plester, Mark Tankersley, Anne-Solenne Hatte, Peter Hudson, Nick Hardin, Dan Savier, Damijan Oklopdzic, Bojan Peric
genres: Action & Adventure, Mystery & Suspense, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: Emilie Warnock (Maggie Grace), the daughter of the American president, leads a humanitarian mission to MS One, an outer-space prison in which the 500 most dangerous criminals from Earth are kept in a state of artificial sleep. Just as Emilie arrives, the now-awakened prisoners stage a violent rebellion, and she and the MS One crew are taken hostage. Emilie's only chance for salvation lies with Snow (Guy Pearce), a wrongly convicted agent who has been promised his freedom if he saves her.
review_content: Cavalierly conceived, generically titled and derivatively plotted. It feels like a missed chance because Pearce and Grace came ready to play.
Snow is an overwritten hero who talks like a sitcom character. Every line is a wisecrack, a gag, or what he fondly thinks of as a witticism.
Pearce gets into his groove swiftly, owns it and remains entertaining. The rest of the movie, however, would work better as a video game.
It's laughably over the top but Pearce, a decent actor, anchors it somewhere between Escape From New York and The Transformers.
Yes, it's cheesy and derivative. But Guy Pearce and Maggie Grace elevate the material, and it never takes itself seriously.
Too serious to be a parody and too stupid to be a viable action pic, Lockout floats like space junk in the final frontier.
More than any masculine heroics, Pearce's primary job is maintaining the tone: smug, irreverent, and giddily punch-drunk.
Most of the time "Lockout" is pleasant enough, not something to recommend to a friend, but enjoyable in the moment.
Shoddy special effects and the surface-level sass of the president's daughter leave this one spinning in low orbit.
Lockout is genre all the way. The film wears its colors proudly, but it also, alas, wears out its welcome.
A putrid film that comes dead-weighted with hammy one-liners and a plot so silly it borders on comedy...
It does a splendid job of putting the pale into imitation and draining the life out of derivative.
Shallow, silly yet infectiously good-natured, this is as guiltily pleasurable as dystopia gets.
Movies like this are supposed to be ridiculous on some level. It's part of the fun. But, dang.
I kept waiting for Nicolas Cage to show up. Or Katherine Heigl. Or, god forbid, both.
Lockout is the kind of manly nonsense no one wants to make anymore.
"Lockout" is meat-and-potatoes filmmaking at its most basic.
"Lockout" never busts out of its cheesy concept.
There's cheap, and then there's this rip-off.
Mostly "Lockout" is lost in space.

actors: Kari Matchett, Robbie Amell, Penny Eizenga, Lawrence Bayne, Jai Jai Jones, Alex Mallari Jr., Shaun Benson, Sung Kang, Aaron Abrams, Martin Roach, Nneka Elliott, Matthew Gouveia, Kevin Claydon, Stephen Amell, Laysla De Oliveira
movie_info: A desperate young man possessing special powers clashes with a police force after committing a petty crime.
review_content: [It] isn't perfect... - it's a bit too relentlessly dour and humourless - but it does a remarkable job in bringing a believable alternative world to the screen on the sort of resources that would barely pay for the credit sequence in an X-Men movie
An investment that definitely paid off, Code 8 is a thrill a minute must-see that delivers a fresh take on superpowers and features a scene-stealing performance from Robbie Amell.
Code 8 is an electrifying film featuring ordinary people with powers in a tough world. It's a gritty and realistic take that's a nice change of pace in the superhero genre.
It isn't groundbreaking, but it does skillfully combine several genres, including sci-fi, superheroes, and even heist movies, while getting quite creative at certain points
Code 8 works better as a proof of concept than a standalone sci-fi thriller, serving up fascinating world-building with a fairly basic story.
There is a rich world to explore here, and it seems that the Amells will get the opportunity to delve further into the tales of Lincoln City.
'Code 8' reminds us that ambition and love for the project carry over to what is seen on the screen. [Full Review in Spanish]
Jeff Chan's futuristic CODE 8 hits hard with the struggle of fringe dwellers with supernatural powers in a harsh society.
Either way, it's a lot of future to absorb in 98 minutes. But in the spirit of the movie I say: More powers to him.
Super-power action tale falls short; violence, language.
More interesting looking than actually interesting

actors: Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo, Chris Evans, Scarlett Johansson, Don Cheadle, Benedict Cumberbatch, Tom Holland, Chadwick Boseman, Zoe Saldana, Karen Gillan, Tom Hiddleston, Paul Bettany, Elizabeth Olsen, Anthony Mackie
movie_info: Iron Man, Thor, the Hulk and the rest of the Avengers unite to battle their most powerful enemy yet -- the evil Thanos. On a mission to collect all six Infinity Stones, Thanos plans to use the artifacts to inflict his twisted will on reality. The fate of the planet and existence itself has never been more uncertain as everything the Avengers have fought for has led up to this moment.
review_content: If only the film were better modulated, or perhaps longer, or more elegantly shaped, or ... well, it's hard to say exactly what's wrong here.
Ten years ago this month, the Marvel universe was launched with the fresh, lively, relatively easygoing "Iron Man." It seems more like 100.
Be sure to stick around, empty popcorn bag in hand, for the post-credits scene, which left me wanting another sequel. Preferably tomorrow.
A movie that mostly gets it right - and isn't afraid to go for truly dramatic moments, or remind us that even superheroes can be mortal.
There's just too much of it. A victim of its own success, there are just too many appealing characters here to stuff into one story.
"Infinity War" isn't just a proper sequel to that film; it's also the towering peak all these Marvel movies have been building to.
Infinity War is a wildly ambitious and entertaining ride in which good old fashioned team work just about carries the day.
All the past decade's Marvel movies have been heading toward this showdown. Turns out the payoff was worth the wait.
After 10 years of lean, threadbare, Lilliputian tales, Marvel Studios has, thank heavens, finally decided to go big.
Avengers: Infinity War knows what it wants to be and goes about pursuing that goal with relentless intensity.
A superhero-space-opera that will knock you off your feet and quite possibly bring a lump to your throat.
"Infinity War" is big, blustery and brave, taking viewers to places that they may not be used to going.
Some of the sequences are undeniably thrilling but, at about 2-1/2 hours, overkill sets in early.
A film that's overlong and overstuffed but somehow avoids being a chore to watch.
Even by Marvel's own standards of serviceable mediocrity, Infinity War fails.
The final moments of Infinity War are haunting and impactful and mysterious.
This is definitely a fun movie. But it doesn't make for a great movie.
The high doesn't last, but it's dizzying all the same.
Welcome to the ultimate superhero extravaganza.
It should never have been this good.

actors: Eric Balfour, Scottie Thompson, Brittany Daniel, Crystal Reed, Neil Hopkins, David Zayas, Donald Faison, Robin Gammell, Tanya Newbould, J. Paul Boehmer, Phet Mahathongdy, Byron McIntyre, Jackie Marin, Tony Black, Eliza Till
movie_info: Jarrod (Eric Balfour) and Elaine (Scottie Thompson) take a trip to Southern California to visit his friend, Terry (Donald Faison), for a fun getaway, but it turns into a weekend of terror. During the night a cluster of strange, mesmerizing lights signals the arrival of an alien invasion. As thousands of terrified people are pulled into the maws of giant alien ships, Jarrod and his companions must use every skill they have to survive global genocide.
review_content: While flawed, few will go see Skyline and not have fun.
Skyline is pure eye candy, but it's mighty tasty.
full review at Movies for the Masses
You'll be glad when it ends....!
Behold: it's Indepen-dunce Day.
an ordeal by tedium

Trapped inside what looks like a Marina del Rey condo complex, the principals raise and lower the blinds, run up and down the stairs and occasionally venture outside, while the audience, if it has the energy, yells: "No! Don't do that! That's stupid!"

We get some watchable flurries of hunt-'em-down suspense between the interminable kvetchings of the human prey, but the only salient reason to see this is the creature design, by those HR Giger-inspired wizards Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff Jr.

More and more frequent attacks by the brain-sucking outer space invaders... don't come so much as frights or thrills as they do a form of relief; as long as the mayhem's going on, we're spared the dialogue.
The Strauses used their tech savvy to make a marvel of logistics that looks every bit as slick as a studio tentpole. It's just a shame they haven't figured out a way to CG a decent story. Yet.
So bland it's easy to forget the title only minutes after exiting, this Emmerich-by-numbers invasion movie exists only to offer you the cutting edge in unconvincing special effects.
The only fascinating thing about Skyline is that that such a mad muddle of a movie can even exists in an era of corporate homogeneity and purported quality-controlled.
How this managed not to go direct-to-DVD (and actually get a wide distribution rather than just a handful-of-theaters dump) is one of 2010's great cinematic mysteries.
The science-fiction thriller Skyline falls squarely -- and a little endearingly -- into the Roger Corman tradition of cheap cash-ins on popular hits.
There's a kind of magic that happens when a movie inspires complete strangers to ridicule it to each other on the way out of the theatre.
Imagine it's 1953 and you're watching a movie called 'Brain Suckers from Planet X', and you might even have a good time.
These aren't moviemakers who live even in other movies, let alone the world. They live in hard drives.
It's like a trip to a Kmart staffed by the ugliest beings imaginable.
"Skyline" plays like an effects guru's resume reel, not a movie.
Wait for the DVD and you won't miss a thing.

country: USA, UK, Bulgaria, Canada, Portugal, France
actors: Mark Stanley, Brian Gleeson, Nadya Keranova, Maria Tepavicharova, Ana Tabakova, Milla Jovovich, Penelope Mitchell, Terry Randal, Ian McShane, David Harbour, Mario de la Rosa, Christopher Mata, Atanas Srebrev, Dawn Sherrer, Michael Heath
movie_info: While battling a trio of rampaging giants, the legendary half-demon Hellboy encounters Nimue the Blood Queen, an ancient resurrected sorceress who's out to avenge a past betrayal. Suddenly caught in a clash between the supernatural and the human, Hellboy soon becomes hell-bent on stopping Nimue without triggering the end of the world.
review_content: This all hurtles at a relentless, unforgiving pace, glued together with many, many crunchy guitar licks. You don't so much as watch this movie as submit to being pummeled by it.
Watching the "Hellboy" reboot is like eating a rice cake - you don't feel bad afterward, but at the same time you're not entirely sure you really experienced anything at all.
In the end, the movie leaves us stuck with unmoving drama and increasingly numbing carnage, delivered with a hand as heavy as Hellboy's monstrously oversized right meathook.
Comparing it to Del Toro's 2004 original and 2008 sequel is like making an analogy between a Broadway production and a high school stage show.
A decade on, this largely routine reboot from British director Neil Marshall...is no compensation for whatever we missed out on back then.
The sentimental father-son subplot is Hellboy at its most laughably absurd, highlighting the chasm between its script and its direction.
Look, I'm glad expensive movies are R-rated again. But this is the doofiest kind of maturity: boring CGI bloodsprays, F-bombs galore.
The race for worst movie of the year is heating up. You could even say it's hotter than hell, now that "Hellboy" has taken the lead.
It ends up simply being a franchise reboot damned to be restaged as its own bloody hell. Some things are better left dead.
As much as it attempts to inject fresh life into the franchise, it winds up feeling more like the walking dead.
You will never realize how much you need Guillermo del Toro in your life until you see the reboot of Hellboy.
Ugly, obnoxious and yowlingly witless, with nothing to say for itself that doesn't start with the letter F.
It's two hours long but feels like an eternity, lurching incoherently from one noisy set-piece to another.
This is the Vitamix school of film-making. Cram everything into the blender, add gore and press "whizz".
If it was my call, I'd write nothing about the movie and leave this space blank for readers' notes.
At two hours, "Hellboy" feels closer to three. And yet there still seems to be something missing.
Violence and vulgarity replace the humor and poetry of Guillermo del Toro's superhero films.
The new Hellboy lands with a thud that's loud and dark - but almost instantly forgettable.
Like two giant horns protruding from your noggin, "Hellboy" is one hell of a headache.
Watching Hellboy is my new personal idea of hell.

actors: Levi Eisenblätter, Rosie Shaw, Eugen Bauder, Livia Matthes, Jarah Maria Anders, Caroline Peters, Laura de Boer, Grégoire Gros, Alexander Skarsgård, Seyneb Saleh, Robert Sheehan, Paul Rudd, Daniel Fathers, Nikki Lamborn, Noel Clarke
genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: In a Berlin of the future, a mute bartender's search for his missing lady-love takes him deeper and deeper into the city's criminal underbelly.
review_content: "Mute" is by no means unwatchable, but ultimately inspires us to re-watch the movies that inspired it.
Fans of Moon and Source Code be warned: Mute is sadly, almost tragically, not worth the wait.
Duncan Jones' latest film is an crushingly disappointing disaster. [Full Review in Spanish]
If anything, Mute serves as a reminder that some dream projects should remain on the shelf.
It won't be for everyone, but it's something strangely compelling to watch.
Another inimitable chapter in an increasingly fascinating filmography.
The worst thing to happen to Justin Theroux this week.
... languishes to extremes... [Full review in Spanish]
Futuristic thriller has brutality, sex, cursing.

Skarsgrd is just frustratingly silent and dull, to the point where it feels less like he's a mute and more like he's just doing the whole hard-boiled, Liam Neeson, no-need-for-words-when-I-can-thump-henchmen-with-my-table-leg character thing .
With an insipid script, no narrative line, and a cast of unlikable characters, Mute has to get by on looks-neon Cold War hand-me-downs with all the workmanship of journeyman TV.
But it's never a great sign when your lead is upstaged by the supporting players, and for all its good looks, "Mute" ultimately doesn't have a whole lot to say.
As a production project it was, apparently, stuck in "development hell" for more than a decade. Sometimes projects are stuck in development hell for a reason.
Early trailers made it look like a neon-noir cross between Blade Runner and The Fifth Element. Sadly, it's just another airless dud in red packaging.
Jones is clearly striving to develop something fresh out of well-trodden material, and Mute at least exhumes Jones' stature as a notable auteur.
Mute is more interesting as a bullet-point list of absurdities than as a two-hour film. Yet, Jones continues to have my attention.
Mute possesses so little sense of style, of directorial muscularity, that it fizzles out long before its 125 minutes are up.
Skrsgard simply occupies space onscreen. If acting is music, he is noise, a series of vaguely related sounds.
Somewhere in here a reasonable film exists, but Mute is rather less than the sum of its parts.
A mishmash of ideas in search of a movie.

actors: Paul Rudd, Evangeline Lilly, Michael Peña, Walton Goggins, Bobby Cannavale, Judy Greer, T.I., David Dastmalchian, Hannah John-Kamen, Abby Ryder Fortson, Randall Park, Michelle Pfeiffer, Laurence Fishburne, Michael Douglas, Divian Ladwa
genres: Action & Adventure, Comedy, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: Scott Lang is grappling with the consequences of his choices as both a superhero and a father. Approached by Hope van Dyne and Dr. Hank Pym, Lang must once again don the Ant-Man suit and fight alongside the Wasp. The urgent mission soon leads to secret revelations from the past as the dynamic duo finds itself in an epic battle against a powerful new enemy.
review_content: "Ant-Man and the Wasp" is disposable pop trash, not worth taking seriously for a moment and therefore eminently worthy of your attention at this moment.
While Ant-Man's technically "the star," this is most definitely the Wasp's movie to own, and the smirking, enjoyably no-nonsense role fits Lilly well.
There's a fresh sense of looseness, lots of play and pockets of weird humor... That's the stuff that makes the movie really sing - not sting.
There is more of an emotional underpinning to this one than there was in the first one because of the Michelle Pfeiffer element to it.
Ant-Man And The Wasp is arguably even more of a straightforward comedy, to the point that it doesn't even have a primary villain.
This "Ant-Man" entry stakes out its own corner of the Marvel Universe sandbox as a throwback to '80s-style childlike adventure.
"Ant-Man and the Wasp," the first sequel to 2015's "Ant-Man," is barely an exoskeleton next to its much better predecessor.
In a cinematic world crowded with comic-book flicks, "Ant-Man and the Wasp" stands out. And that's no small accomplishment.
I'm tired of saying "the special effects are great" when nothing else in a movie is. But, yes, it's spectacularly staged.
Ant-Man and the Wasp may not be the best anything, but, like its perpetually challenged hero, it is plenty good enough.
Ant-Man and the Wasp is all in pursuit of some MCU masterplan. If only the journey there was a bit more of a buzz.
A Marvel film giving off the repeated vibe that in some other space and time, Pixar might have made it.
Its intent is limited to amusing and diverting for a couple of hours of high-summer fun. That it does.
The essence of "Ant-Man" is inherently silly, and that's where the strength of the new movie lies.
The storyline feels a little thin and moth-eaten in parts but this sequel is plenty of fun.
The thrill of the film is watching Ant-Man and the Wasp team up and raise hell together.
"Ant-Man and the Wasp" has its moments, but it doesn't quite measure up to the original.
Even when things get ultra-corny, Ant-Man and the Wasp keeps merrily buzzing along.
A light, watered-down tonic leading up to next May's Avengers 4 extravaganza.
The film cuts superheroes and their oh-so-serious issues down to size.

actors: Sam Gittins, Neerja Naik, Abigail Cruttenden, David Bradley, Grant Masters, Holly Weston, Kris Saddler
movie_info: On Christmas Day, a family wakes up to find a mysterious black substance surrounding its house, and its TV screen broadcasts a single message: "Stay Indoors and Await Further Instructions."
review_content: Await Further Instructions launches into survivalist psychotics that embrace walled-in escalation, always building towards "that" finale. The ride is filled with highs and lows, but damn if Johnny Kevorkian doesn't stick that landing.

Await Further Instructions deliberately resists pitting the characters' beliefs against each other in favour of keeping the conflict shallow and straightforward...This is particularly true once the body count begins to rise

A horror film in the tradition of Night of the Living Dead, gathering a group of people in a house with an unexplained threat outside and observing as fear gives way to anger and violence. It's the Bottle Episode from Hell.

All at once tense family drama, Cronenbergian horror, social satire and sci-fi reimagining of the Nativity, Await Further Instructions shows how difficult it is to escape the domineering, malevolent influence of the media.

There's bleak realism behind the comedy, Cruttenden's twitchy performance suggesting that power games in this household are nothing new. The final scenes, anarchic and glorious, will not easily be forgotten.

Gavin Williams' script has managed to pre-empt so much of the division and bias that we see in today's society and skilfully focuses it back on the root problem: hereditary abuse and toxic masculinity.
[The] unraveling nightmare is a visceral, pertinent examination of the human condition as rules of order and decency break down and a chilling, mysterious new reality takes over.
A single situation story that explores the horrors of family, conformity and our relationship with technology; go in fresh and enjoy the journey of Await Further Instructions.
Await Further Instructions comes along at the perfect time, evoking much of the horror in a post-Brexit/Trump landscape, from the U.K. to here in Canada and the U.S.
Despite its amalgam of styles and influences, Await Further Instructions transcends mere pastiche, adding a unique wrinkle to otherwise familiar terrain.
In its final stretch, Await Further Instructions reveals itself as a hollow, hamfisted polemic, one with all the profundity of a bumper sticker.
Genre fans will enjoy the escalating mayhem and some moments of inventive, audacious grisliness.
sends out an agreeably grisly, condemnatory and satisfactory signal

An important subject doesn't necessarily make for a thrilling satire/social critique and Kevorkian and Williams simply aren't outlandish enough to land their half-baked ideas about television's dominating influence.
There's armrest-clutching brilliance in the way this sweatily tense low-budget British horror lays out a family Christmas from hell, and then cranks it up into something truly gruesome.
This British sci-fi thriller is like the violent offspring of "Black Mirror."

actors: Josh Hartnett, Bipasha Basu, Tamsin Egerton, James Mackay, Alice Englert, Simone Kessell, Abhay Deol, Aegina De Vas, Andrea Deck, Matthew Beard, Bille Brown, Steve Nicolson, Vijay Thombre, Yatin Karyekar, Roshan Seth
movie_info: An impossible love blooms across two time periods and continents.
review_content: Joffe seems well aware that this is a story not worth telling ... the filmmaking is so hopelessly uninspired that Hartnett's Scottish accent is somehow not its most glaring flaw.
A shamelessly derivative and preposterous would-be blockbuster that goofily fashions itself as a sweeping romance, time-travel sci-fi tale, and gallant period piece all at once.
A slew of half-baked characters and a derivative, white-man-in-a-foreign-land plot line make it hard to recommend, despite a handful of inspired moments.
Instead of evolving into intriguing lunacy, "The Lovers" loses a critical battle with coherency.
Flailing through centuries, it lacks any meaningful connection between the two timelines.
It's so deadly and unintentionally funny (I hope) that it practically defies description. Mr. Joff should go back to film school as soon as possible.
As one of the film's many forgettable characters so eloquently puts it, "This stinks worse than an oyster's fart."
Suckers for romance likely won't complain, but this Josh Hartnett time-travel epic is nuts.

directors: Bob Persichetti, Peter Ramsey, Rodney Rothman
actors: Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson, Hailee Steinfeld, Mahershala Ali, Brian Tyree Henry, Lily Tomlin, Luna Lauren Velez, Zoë Kravitz, John Mulaney, Kimiko Glenn, Nicolas Cage, Kathryn Hahn, Liev Schreiber, Chris Pine, Natalie Morales
genres: Action & Adventure, Animation, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy
movie_info: Bitten by a radioactive spider in the subway, Brooklyn teenager Miles Morales suddenly develops mysterious powers that transform him into the one and only Spider-Man. When he meets Peter Parker, he soon realizes that there are many others who share his special, high-flying talents. Miles must now use his newfound skills to battle the evil Kingpin, a hulking madman who can open portals to other universes and pull different versions of Spider-Man into our world.
review_content: If this kind of risk-taking and artist-driven creativity can exist in Hollywood's biggest money-making genre, then our superhero movie future is filled with hope.
Like the very knowing writing, these visual pyrotechnics are underwritten by a sense of strain, as if someone somewhere were terrified of viewers losing interest.
The film's take-home message, if you want to call it that, is that we all have a little Spidey in us: "What makes you different is what makes you Spider-Man."
Look, I get it. I'm weary of superhero movies, too. But "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" isn't just a superhero movie. It's also a great movie.
The visuals are also outstanding (New York is a neon-lit fever dream) and the action is expertly done. It is, simply, the best Spider-Man yet.
By the time it's chucked a Spider-pig (yes, really), Banksy jokes and buckets of Day-glo-bathed spectacle at you, resistance will be futile.
"Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" occasionally feels overly antic, but that's because it's brimming with imagination and energy.
Yet with great power comes great responsibility. And one such responsibility, as a critic, is to admit when you've made a mistake.
How fitting that just a month after Stan Lee died, the most detailed homage conceivable to his art and legacy lands in cinemas.
The delights of "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" bring a newfound sense of joy and playfulness to the beloved character
The greatest triumph and biggest surprise of the film is that it is an LSD freak-out on par with 2001: A Space Odyssey.
The animation captures a comic book's sense of engagement and imagination but the visuals never overwhelm the story.
This is the seventh Spider-Man feature film in 16 years, but this universe has rarely felt so fresh.
Never did hyper-kinesis seem so much like standstill. So much rush. So little panache.
[Makes] a strong case that animation is the natural medium for the comic book movie.
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse might be the best Spider-Man film ever made.
It's the best stand-alone film to feature the iconic character so far.
As far as this decade is concerned, this is the ultimate Spider-Man.
"Into the Spider-Verse" is pure fun, nonstop from start to finish.
Spider-Verse has plenty of small delights, and it looks unique.

actors: Maika Monroe, Matt O'Leary, Arnar Jónsson, Gunnar Helgason, Berglind Rós Sigurðardóttir
movie_info: After a flash of light shoots across the sky, a couple (Maika Monroe, Matt O'Leary) on vacation in Iceland wake up to discover that everyone in the world is missing. Now, they must fight for survival while trying to make sense out of what happened.
review_content: Strives to be meditative, examining art, life, and the pain of living, but it never achieve its full dramatic wingspan, wasting its potential on actors incapable of keeping their characters compelling.
This issue of character development is largely what holds the film back. Without understanding what makes this couple tick, we are left voyeurs in a world that we cannot understand.
A pretty blur of an apocalypse happens to pretty, blurry people in this dull SF drama. This end of the world brought to you by the Reykjavik Tourist Board.
Like its titular aesthetic definition, Bokeh remains completely out of focus both narratively and thematically.
The half-baked philosophizing and predictable outcome make the picture an endurance test for your patience.
It's not really the subject that's important, but how we interpret what's going on in the background.
Charming stars and pleasant scenery are all well and good, but can only carry Bokeh so far.
Generic last-couple-on-Earth sci-fi that's too empty to offer anything deep or fun.
This is a film for the patient and that patience goes largely unrewarded.

What sets "Bokeh" apart among the "low-key apocalypse" cinematic subgenre is not what happens, but what doesn't happen. It's the unknowing that is their undoing. The result is a subtle but ultimately profound humanist message.
Only worthwhile storytellers could take an elevator pitch like this one (the last two people on Earth) and produce long-lasting curiosity about its inherent beauty and horror.
Beautiful and challenging, Bokeh has a pristine look and chilling feel of its own that contributes enormously to the mood and tone of the whole film.
Unimaginative and unconvincing ...

actors: Brie Larson, Jacob Tremblay, Sean Bridgers, Wendy Crewson, Sandy McMaster, Matt Gordon, Amanda Brugel, Joe Pingue, Joan Allen, Zarrin Darnell-Martin, Cas Anvar, William H. Macy, Jee-Yun Lee, Randal Edwards, Justin Mader
movie_info: Held captive for years in an enclosed space, a woman (Brie Larson) and her young son (Jacob Tremblay) finally gain their freedom, allowing the boy to experience the outside world for the first time.
review_content: "Room" could turn mawkish at any moment, or merely sentimental. That it stays honest and true is a tribute to its makers.
Almost everything seen in the first half of Room will set an audience to wondering: "What would I do? How would I cope?"
Room is honest and challenging but it's more uplifting than one might expect from a film with such a horrific backstory.
By its lyrical end, you recognize anew the beauty of small miracles - sunshine, a backyard, a new morning, an open door.
This is one of those situations in which mere words seem insufficient in describing a film's profoundly moving power.
What could have been a sordid, exploitive film is really a tribute to a mother's love, and a child's imagination.
This dramatic thriller is small-scale but profound, with great performances from Larson and a young Tremblay.
It's good, but also a somewhat glassy experience, lacking the cathartic lift-off we might have anticipated.
Room works as a film because of the completely engaging performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay.
Room may not be a pleasant place to spend two hours, but it's an unsettling experience you won't forget.
Larson delivers every line to perfection and, as it happens, there's not one weak link in the cast.
What happens in this tiny space gives you more to think about than 10 blockbuster action films.
"Room" goes its own way, in a state of poetic realism that can break your heart.
Dopey as the film is on a plot level, it's equally vapid in its psychology.
An extraordinary film so powerful and unforgettable that it must be seen.
Abrahamson seamlessly translates Donaghue's work into cinematic terms.
This is one of the best movies of the decade.
A cowardly movie about brave people.
A soul-stirring feel-good weepie.
One of the year's best films.

actors: Teo Halm, Astro, Reese Hartwig, Ella Wahlestedt, Jason Gray-Stanford, Algee Smith, Cassius M. Willis, Sonya Leslie, Kerry O'Malley, Virginia Louise Smith, Peter Mackenzie, Valerie Wildman, Roger Hewlett, Mary Pat Gleason, Marilyn Giacomazzi
movie_info: After a construction project begins in their neighborhood, best friends Tuck (Brian "Astro" Bradley), Alex (Teo Halm) and Munch (Reese C. Hartwig) begin receiving strange, encoded messages on their cell phones. They immediately inform their parents and the authorities, but when no one takes them seriously, the youths decide to crack the code themselves and trace the messages to their source. The youths' curiosity leads them to a robotic extraterrestrial who desperately needs their help.
review_content: "Earth to Echo" recalls - but doesn't live up to - films like "Super 8" and "Stand By Me," stories of youth, innocence and the Summer That Changed Everything.
With so few kid-friendly movies on the summer slate, Earth to Echo offers a heartfelt and often comic adventure. For that, some copycatting can be forgiven.
The mildewed found-footage technique allows some tension to build from offscreen action, but also renders the knockoff John Williams score inexplicable.
Despite its flaws and recycled parts, "Earth to Echo" is engaging enough to impress pre-teen audiences and nostalgic enough to please their parents.
The young cast's interaction is terrific. You might come for the turn-on-your-heartlight riff, but you'll stay for the connection the boys share.
If the movie is a waste, at least it's an instructive one, signaling just how offensive children's entertainment might become in the YouTube era.
This kind of magpie filmmaking can work with a sincere core, but the big problem is that Earth to Echo lacks one. It's all spare parts.
Almost anything's possible if you stick with your friends, work together and remember how to get home. A nice message, in any decade.
Savvily, and perhaps cynically, seeks to be the first to surf what I fear will be the new cinematic language: automatic Google Glass.
The movie's continually reiterated theme of lasting friendship is unlikely to affect even the most impressionable young viewers ...
The movie tracks "E.T." so closely ... that you can almost hear the legal ice cracking beneath the children's bicycle tires.
It's as if there's a barrier between the viewer and the story that never comes down.
It is a smart, visually dynamic film, but audiences may miss Spielberg's wonderment.
This cutesy E.T.-like sci-fi drama is utterly undermined by its own shooting style.
Sure, Earth to Echo is derivative, but it's refreshingly updated. Echo, I.M. home.
A digital remastering of E.T. for the smartphone social-media kinderkultur.
The movie feels less like a weak "E.T." than a substandard "Mac and Me."
Every generation deserves its own visiting extra-terrestrial.
Imitation should be flattering, not flattening.
First, the script is dumb.

actors: Sharlto Copley, Dev Patel, Ninja, Yo-Landi Visser, Jose Pablo Cantillo, Hugh Jackman, Sigourney Weaver, Brandon Auret, Johnny Selema, Anderson Cooper, Maurice Carpede, Jason Cope, Kevin Otto, Chris Shields, Bill Marchant
movie_info: In the near future, a mechanized police force patrols the streets and deals with lawbreakers -- but now, the people are fighting back. When one police droid is stolen and given new programming, he acquires the ability to feel and think for himself. While the robot, dubbed "Chappie (Sharlto Copley)," puzzles out human behavior, the authorities begin to see him as a danger to mankind and order; they will stop at nothing to ensure that Chappie is the last of his kind.
review_content: By the time the plot skitters completely off the rails, that Chappie is Blomkamp's best movie is compelling evidence that he shouldn't be the one making them.
It may be too sloppy and indulgent to actually call good, but that still leaves room for words like heartfelt, trippy, personal, and even admirable.
Sci-fi filmmaker Neill Blomkamp bolts together used and stolen parts for his robot movie Chappie, and the lamentable result is far from riveting.
Low on meaning, but full of high-velocity chases, helicopter pursuits, and weapons blasting around empty warehouses marred by graffiti and trash.
A brawny, inventive action romp that's as happy firing rockets at helicopters as it is contemplating the Cartesian model of mind-body dualism.
There's material in Chappie for a worthwhile motion picture but too little is explored by Blomkamp to make this worth a trip to a theater.
There are some nice special-effects here, and great production design, but Blomkamp forgot to give us any characters to latch onto.
So kinetic, so captivatingly crackerjack that attention deficit is no danger for the audience even if it is for the artist.
"Chappie" is all over the place, employing a cloying, "Patch Adams"-like sentimentality and abandoning logic at every turn.
The concept is undeniably compelling, but portions of this dystopian action thriller begin to feel like a video game.
This is a well-meaning film with a good idea that unfortunately stumbles on its way to its less-than-satisfying end.
There's something fearlessly uncool about the film, which suffers mostly from being made 30 years too late.
A loud and unpleasant "RoboCop" rehash that gives us no one to root for and nothing to think about.
Blomkamp's strength lies in his unabashed populism, an extension of his sympathy with the underdog.
One of those incongruous Franken-films that's simultaneously bombastically brutal and treacly.
I didn't think there was room in my heart for another kind-bot-in-a-cruel-world. I was wrong.
I haven't been as happy to see a movie end since the third "Transformers."
After the disappointment of Elysium, Blomkamp is back on his game.
Like Chappie, the movie seems human, but has a cold metal heart.
A misjudgment from metallic head to titanium toe.

actors: Keri Russell, Josh Hamilton, Dakota Goyo, Kadan Rockett, J.K. Simmons, L.J. Benet, Rich Hutchman, Myndy Crist, Annie Thurman, Jake Brennan, Ron Ostrow, Tom Costello, Marion Kerr, Alyvia Alyn Lind, Josh Stamberg
movie_info: Lacy (Keri Russell) and Daniel Barrett (Josh Hamilton) share a peaceful life in the suburbs with their sons, Jesse (Dakota Goyo) and Sam (Kadan Rockett). However, that peace soon shatters with a series of disturbing events that escalate. When it becomes clear that their family is being targeted by an unimaginably terrifying, deadly -- and possibly alien -- threat, Daniel and Lacy draw on their courage and determination to protect their family and identify what is after them.
review_content: There are some good ideas here, just not enough frights.
Dire and unsettling, it's ultimately disappointing.
The movie promises fireworks--and it delivers.
Puts a new spin on a tired subgenre.
It's never uninteresting.
A baffling bore.

Really the biggest problem with Dark Skies is that Stewart can never quite decide just what story he is telling or whether to focus on this character or that, instead struggling to string together scares regardless of how they fit together overall.

It's a generic repository of everything that's currently en vogue in commercial horror: a PG-13 haunted-house movie with body possession, lots of digital shocks, and some of the surveillance-cam creep of the Paranormal Activity series.

Alien abductions are a truly terrifying idea, and building an alien abduction movie on the template of "Poltergeist" is a great idea. But "Poltergeist" had one thing "Dark Skies" is sorely in need of: follow-through.
